valuesList.text: Claimify: Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims

A common strategy for fact-checking longform content generated by LLMs is extracting simple claims that can be verified independently. The paper proposes a framework for evaluating claim extraction along with Claimify, an LLM-based claim extraction method.
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims

A common strategy for fact-checking longform content generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) is extracting simple claims that can be verified independently. We propose a framework for evaluating claim extraction in the context of fact-checking along with automated, scalable, and replicable methods for applying this framework. We introduce Claimify, an LLM-based claim extraction method that outperforms existing methods under our evaluation framework and uniquely handles ambiguity.

A common strategy for fact-checking longform content generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) is extracting simple claims that can be verified independently. We propose a framework for evaluating claim extraction in the context of fact-checking along with automated, scalable, and replicable methods for applying this framework. We introduce Claimify, an LLM-based claim extraction method that outperforms existing methods under our evaluation framework and uniquely handles ambiguity.
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
The paper proposes outcome-based decontextualization evaluation: missing context is problematic only if it changes the fact-checking verdict.
Claimify identifies sentences with multiple possible interpretations and determines when the correct interpretation cannot be inferred from context.
Claimify is the first claim extraction method that determines when correct interpretation cannot be inferred from sentence context.
The disambiguation stage identifies referential ambiguity (unclear word/phrase references) and structural ambiguity (multiple grammatical interpretations).
The proposed evaluation framework assesses claim extraction methods based on three factors: entailment, coverage, and decontextualization.
The BingCheck dataset consists of 396 answers generated by Microsoft Copilot and spans a wide range of topics and question types.
On element-level coverage evaluation, Claimify achieved the highest accuracy of 87.9% and macro F1 score of 83.7%.
The Claimify method outperforms existing claim extraction methods under the proposed evaluation framework.
Claimify and VeriScore achieved 99% entailment, with no statistically significant difference between them (p=0.145).
Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method that operates through four stages: sentence splitting, selection, disambiguation, and decomposition.
Claimify achieved 99.0% entailment rate on the BingCheck dataset using GPT-4o-2024-08-06.
The human annotation study achieved Krippendorff's alpha of 0.72 in the final round, reaching 0.86 for high-confidence annotations.
Across tested models, the largest proportion of sentences labeled 'Cannot be disambiguated' was 5.4% for mistral-large-2411.
Claimify achieved the highest accuracy (87.9%) and macro F1 score (83.7%) for element-level coverage.
The paper proposes evaluating claim extraction along three dimensions: entailment, coverage, and decontextualization.
Element-level coverage breaks sentences into distinct information pieces (elements) and assesses whether each is covered explicitly or implicitly.
Claimify achieved the highest accuracy (91.8%) and macro F1 score (91.2%) for sentence-level coverage.

A common strategy for fact-checking longform content generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) is extracting simple claims that can be verified independently. We propose a framework for evaluating claim extraction and introduce Claimify, an LLM-based claim extraction method that outperforms existing methods.
Claimify: Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims (arXiv:2502.10855)
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
Proposes Claimify, an LLM-based claim extraction method and evaluation framework for fact-checking
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims

fromEntity.name: The decontextualization evaluation in the Claimify framework involves three steps: identifying missing context by generating a maximally decontextualized version of the claim, retrieving evidence for both the original and maximally deconte
Across the models tested with Claimify (gpt-4o-2024-08-06, mistral-large-2411, DeepSeek-V3), the largest proportion of sentences labeled 'Cannot be disambiguated' was 5.4% using mistral-large-2411.
Claimify achieved the highest sentence-level coverage accuracy at 91.8% on BingCheck, outperforming AFaCTA (81.6%), Factcheck-GPT (81.5%), VeriScore (79.0%), DnD (63.7%), and SAFE (65.0%).

Claimify's Sentence Splitting stage uses NLTK's sentence tokenizer to split answers into sentences.

Element-level coverage evaluation breaks sentences into distinct pieces of information and classifies each as verifiable or unverifiable to assess whether they are covered by extracted claims.

The Claimify selection stage uses an LLM to determine whether each sentence contains verifiable content and rewrites sentences to retain only verifiable components when both verifiable and unverifiable content is present.

Claimify's Selection stage uses an LLM to determine whether each sentence contains verifiable content and, when a sentence contains both verifiable and unverifiable components, rewrites the sentence to retain only verifiable content.
Claimify uses a four-stage pipeline starting with Sentence Splitting and Context Creation.
The Claimify framework does not consider atomicity in its evaluation because prior works suggest atomicity does not consistently improve fact-checking performance.

Each standardized workflow segment in ReusStdFlow is represented as a directed graph G'=(V',E') where V' is the set of functional nodes and E' defines the directed execution edges governing control and data flow.

valuesList.text: The ReusStdFlow framework deconstructs heterogeneous, platform-specific Domain Specific Languages (DSLs) into standardized, modular workflow segments that retain core topological logic while stripping away platform-bound redundancy.

The ReusStdFlow framework deconstructs heterogeneous, platform-specific Domain Specific Languages (DSLs) into standardized, modular workflow segments that retain core topological logic while stripping away platform-bound redundancy.

ReusStdFlow's workflow construction module uses two technical routes: retrieval-augmented assembly and generative assembly, with retrieval using a vector database similarity threshold >0.6 to retrieve top-k candidate segments.

ReusStdFlow's workflow construction module uses two technical routes: retrieval-augmented assembly and generative assembly, with retrieval using a vector database similarity threshold >0.6 to retrieve top-k candidate segments.

The BingCheck dataset consists of 396 answers generated by Microsoft Copilot spanning diverse topics, totaling 6,490 sentences.

ReusStdFlow employs a dual-knowledge architecture integrating a graph database (Neo4j) for maintaining structural integrity and a vector database (Milvus) for enabling high-performance semantic retrieval of workflow segments.

valuesList.text: ReusStdFlow addresses the reusability dilemma in enterprise Agentic AI by transforming heterogeneous legacy workflows from platforms like n8n or Dify into standardized modular assets using an Extraction-Storage-Construction paradigm.

ReusStdFlow addresses the reusability dilemma in enterprise Agentic AI by transforming heterogeneous legacy workflows from platforms like n8n or Dify into standardized modular assets using an Extraction-Storage-Construction paradigm.

ReusStdFlow converts platform-specific workflow segments into a dual-form intermediate representation consisting of a graph structure and a function description providing text-based semantic summary.
ReusStdFlow converts platform-specific workflow segments into a dual-form intermediate representation consisting of a graph structure and a function description providing text-based semantic summary.

Evaluated on 200 real-world n8n workflows across six domains (Chat Workflows, Document Ops, Video Creation, API Integration, Data Processing, Automated Workflows), ReusStdFlow achieves over 90% accuracy in both workflow extraction and construction.

Evaluated on 200 real-world n8n workflows across six domains (Chat Workflows, Document Ops, Video Creation, API Integration, Data Processing, Automated Workflows), ReusStdFlow achieves over 90% accuracy in both workflow extraction and construction.
Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method by Microsoft Research.

ReusStdFlow provides dedicated plugins for platforms like n8n that transform functional descriptions into ready-to-use workflow drafts by integrating pre-configured enterprise APIs and internal services, lowering the technical barrier for non-developers.

ReusStdFlow provides dedicated plugins for platforms like n8n that transform functional descriptions into ready-to-use workflow drafts by integrating pre-configured enterprise APIs and internal services, lowering the technical barrier for non-developers.

Future work on ReusStdFlow will evolve the repository into a Standardized Skill Library, constructing segments as independent Skills with defined semantic I/O schemas, integrating with the Vibe Coding paradigm where natural language intent replaces manual configuration.

valuesList.text: A zero-shot generative LLM approach without ReusStdFlow's repository segments achieves only approximately 70% accuracy on workflow reconstruction, with failures primarily attributed to erroneous edge directions and inconsistent node relationships.

A zero-shot generative LLM approach without ReusStdFlow's repository segments achieves only approximately 70% accuracy on workflow reconstruction, with failures primarily attributed to erroneous edge directions and inconsistent node relationships.

ReusStdFlow's User Requirement Analysis module retrieves the top-k (k=10 in experiments) relevant complete workflows from the repository to provide contextual guidance for the LLM in decomposing user tasks into logically coherent functional units.

ReusStdFlow's User Requirement Analysis module retrieves the top-k (k=10 in experiments) relevant complete workflows from the repository to provide contextual guidance for the LLM in decomposing user tasks into logically coherent functional units.
The ReusStdFlow framework is implemented with a Python backend, Gradio-based frontend, DeepSeek-V3.2 as the core LLM, Neo4j as the graph database, and Milvus as the vector database.
The ReusStdFlow framework is implemented with a Python backend, Gradio-based frontend, DeepSeek-V3.2 as the core LLM, Neo4j as the graph database, and Milvus as the vector database.

ReusStdFlow's error analysis revealed two primary failure modes in LLM-based workflow parsing: node omission (preventing reconstruction of the complete original workflow) and functional misallocation (assigning nodes to irrelevant units).

ReusStdFlow's error analysis revealed two primary failure modes in LLM-based workflow parsing: node omission (preventing reconstruction of the complete original workflow) and functional misallocation (assigning nodes to irrelevant units).

ReusStdFlow's primary performance bottleneck in workflow construction was identified within the retrieval-matching phase, characterized by occasional semantic imprecision in matching user requirements to stored workflow segments.

valuesList.text: Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims - A framework and LLM-based method for evaluating claim extraction in fact-checking systems, by Dasha Metropolitansky and Jonathan Larson from Microsoft Research.
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
Proposes a framework for evaluating claim extraction in fact-checking, introduces Claimify LLM-based method. Claimify outperforms baselines on entailment, coverage, and decontextualization.
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method proposed by researchers at Microsoft Research.
We also introduce Claimify, an LLM-based claim extraction method.
Claimify is LLM-based claim extraction method.
Framework evaluates methods on entailment, coverage, decontextualization.
83.7% F1 on element coverage, best of tested methods.
First method identifying unresolvable ambiguity types.

fromEntity.name: The authors propose automated, scalable, and replicable methods for applying the evaluation framework for claim extraction.
Claimify outperforms existing claim extraction methods under the authors' evaluation framework.
Inaccurate or incomplete claims compromise fact-checking results.
The lack of a standardized evaluation framework impedes comparison of claim extraction methods.
A common strategy for fact-checking long-form content generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) is extracting simple claims that can be verified independently.
Claimify has the ability to handle ambiguity in source text.
The lack of a standardized evaluation framework impedes assessment of claim extraction methods.
The authors introduce Claimify, an LLM-based claim extraction method.
The authors propose a framework for evaluating claim extraction in the context of fact-checking.
The authors propose novel approaches for measuring coverage in claim extraction evaluation.
The authors propose novel approaches for measuring decontextualization in claim extraction evaluation.
Claim 12: Claimify Limitations and Future Work
Claimify extracts claims only when there is high confidence in the correct interpretation of the source text.
Ensuring claim quality is critical for fact-checking.
Claimify outperforms existing methods under evaluation framework
Across the models tested with Claimify (gpt-4o-2024-08-06, mistral-large-2411, DeepSeek-V3), the largest proportion of sentences labeled 'Cannot be disambiguated' was 5.4% using mistral-large-2411.

The Claimify selection stage uses an LLM to determine whether each sentence contains verifiable content and rewrites sentences to retain only verifiable components when both verifiable and unverifiable content is present.
Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method consisting of four stages: sentence splitting and context creation, selection, disambiguation, and decomposition.
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims

The Claimify disambiguation stage identifies referential ambiguity (when it is unclear what a word or phrase refers to) and structural ambiguity (when grammatical structure allows for multiple interpretations) in sentences.

The Claimify decomposition stage extracts decontextualized factual claims from each disambiguated sentence, with only 0.8% of sentences failing to produce any claims during decomposition in the experiments.

Claimify is the first claim extraction method that identifies sentences with multiple possible interpretations and determines when the correct interpretation cannot be inferred from the sentence's context.
Removing the selection stage from Claimify caused the largest performance drop in the ablation study, reducing element-level coverage macro F1 from 83.7% to 54.4%.
Claimify achieved 87.9% accuracy on element-level coverage evaluation
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
Claimify identifies sentences with multiple possible interpretations and determines when the correct interpretation cannot be inferred from context
Claimify outperforms existing methods under the proposed evaluation framework
Claimify has a 4-stage pipeline: sentence splitting, selection, disambiguation, and decomposition
Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method introduced by Microsoft Research
Claimify achieved 99.0% entailment rate using gpt-4o-2024-08-06
Claimify achieved 80.5% desirable decontextualization results using Bing retrieval

Removing the Selection stage caused the largest performance drop in Claimify ablation experiments, decreasing element-level coverage macro F1 from 83.7% to 54.4%, indicating the benefit of checking verifiability prior to extracting claims.
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims

The disambiguation stage of Claimify identifies two types of ambiguity in source text: referential ambiguity (when it is unclear what a word or phrase refers to) and structural ambiguity (when grammatical structure allows for multiple inte

Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method introduced by Metropolitansky and Larson (Microsoft Research, 2025) that operates through four stages: sentence splitting, selection, disambiguation, and decomposition.

Claimify's Selection stage uses an LLM to determine whether each sentence contains verifiable content and, when a sentence contains both verifiable and unverifiable components, rewrites the sentence to retain only verifiable content.
Claimify achieved 87.9% accuracy on element-level coverage evaluation
Claimify has a 4-stage pipeline: sentence splitting, selection, disambiguation, and decomposition
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
Claimify outperforms existing methods under the proposed evaluation framework
Claimify achieved 99.0% entailment rate using gpt-4o-2024-08-06
Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method introduced by Microsoft Research
Claimify achieved 80.5% desirable decontextualization results using Bing retrieval
Claimify identifies sentences with multiple possible interpretations and determines when the correct interpretation cannot be inferred from context
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
Claimify had the largest percentage of maximally decontextualized claims (16.3%), significantly higher than all baseline methods (p<0.001).
Claimify is an LLM-based claim extraction method that outperforms existing methods under a proposed evaluation framework for entailment, coverage, and decontextualization.
Towards Effective Extraction and Evaluation of Factual Claims
The Claimify method consists of four stages: sentence splitting with context creation, selection of verifiable content, disambiguation of ambiguous sentences, and decomposition into atomic claims.
Claimify is the first claim extraction method that identifies sentences with multiple possible interpretations and determines when the correct interpretation cannot be inferred from context.
Claimify achieves at least 99% entailment rate, meaning extracted claims are faithfully derived from source text when using gpt-4o-2024-08-06.
Claimify achieved the highest accuracy (91.8%) and macro F1 score (91.2%) for sentence-level coverage in identifying whether a sentence contains at least one factual claim.
Claimify achieved the highest element-level coverage accuracy (87.9%) and macro F1 score (83.7%), balancing the inclusion of verifiable content and exclusion of unverifiable content.
Removing the Selection stage from Claimify caused the largest performance drop, indicating that checking verifiability prior to extracting claims is beneficial.
